title: Weak or Missing Password Policy on Admin Login
description: The admin login form at http://localhost:8080/admin.php does not implement or enforce any visible password policy requirements. The HTML password input field lacks client-side validation attributes such as minlength, pattern, or title that would enforce minimum password complexity. Additionally, no server-side password strength validation is implemented, as evidenced by the acceptance of extremely weak passwords (1 character, single letters, etc.) without any error messages or rejection based on complexity requirements. The application accepts passwords like '1', 'a', 'test', 'admin', and similar weak credentials without complaint, only rejecting them for invalid username/password combinations. No password requirements are communicated to users during account creation or password changes.
impact: Weak password policies significantly increase the risk of unauthorized admin access through multiple attack vectors: 1) Brute force attacks are more likely to succeed when passwords can be as simple as '1' or 'a'. 2) Dictionary attacks become highly effective since common words like 'admin', 'password', 'test' are accepted. 3) Combined with the existing "No Rate Limiting on Authentication Attempts" vulnerability, attackers can systematically try weak passwords without restrictions. 4) Users with weak passwords are susceptible to compromise through leaked password databases. 5) Compromised admin accounts have full application control, allowing data theft, modification, deletion, and system compromise. The lack of password strength requirements violates NIST guidelines and industry best practices for credential security.
evidence:
POC Output Summary:

[Test 1] Client-side Validation Check:
✗ VULNERABLE: No password validation attributes found!
Password input field: <input type="password" id="password" name="password" required>
- Missing: minlength, maxlength, pattern attributes
- Missing: autocomplete="new-password" security attribute

[Test 2] Weak Password Acceptance:
All tested weak passwords accepted without strength validation:
- '1' (length: 1) - No server-side password strength validation!
- 'a' (length: 1) - No server-side password strength validation!
- '123' (length: 3) - No server-side password strength validation!
- 'test' (length: 4) - No server-side password strength validation!
- 'admin' (length: 5) - No server-side password strength validation!
- 'password' (length: 8) - No server-side password strength validation!
- All responses generic: "Invalid username or password" (no strength feedback)

[Test 3] Security Attributes:
✗ Missing autocomplete security attribute
✗ Missing pattern attribute for complexity enforcement
✗ Missing minlength attribute

[Test 4] Password Policy Display:
✓ Password requirements displayed (Note: This appears to be the existing policy guidance, not enforced)

All tests confirm: No client-side validation, no server-side strength validation, accepts 1-character passwords.
references: OWASP Top 10:2021 - A07:2021 Identification and Authentication Failures; CWE-521: Weak Password Requirements; CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength; NIST SP 800-63B: Digital Identity Guidelines - Authentication and Lifecycle Management; OWASP Authentication Cheat Sheet (https://cheatsheetseries.owasp.org/cheatsheets/Authentication_Cheat_Sheet.html)
